newsitem.title: FRANCE: Lagardere profit jumps in first-half.
newsitem.headline: Lagardere profit jumps in first-half.

text.p: The Lagardere magazines-to-missiles conglomerate reported on Tuesday that its half-year profit jumped 38 percent to 409 million francs ($78.9 million), propelled by gains in its defence activities and a big improvement in its finances.
Operating profit slipped, however, to 976 million francs from 1.08 billion due to weakness in its automotive and audiovisual businesses, the group said in a statement.

Lagardere said its high-tech activities -- set to expand greatly with the acquisition of state electronics group Thomson SA -- showed a 55 percent profit increase as it began billing for several major contracts.
The French government last week said it preferred Lagardere's offer for Thomson SA over a rival bid from Alcatel Alsthom.

Lagardere will focus on Thomson's defence electronics unit Thomson-CSF, merging it with its Matra missiles business, and sell the consumer electronics division -- Thomson Multimedia -- to South Korea's Daewoo Electronics.

The government plans to recapitalise Thomson to the tune of 11 billion francs before selling it to Lagardere for the symbolic sum of one franc after a procedural review by the privatisation commission.
Lagardere said its automotive activities were hit by the weakness in the French car industry and the phase-out of the Espace minivan, which it builds with Renault, ahead of the model replacement.

Lagardere's financial results swung to a gain of 103 million francs in the first half from a charge of 54 million in the first half of 1995 due to lower interest rates and the sale of assets for which provisions had been set aside.
"A study of forecasts for 1996 allows us to confirm the objective of a net attributable profit of one billion francs, given an improvement seen in operating profits in the second half," it said.
Lagardere reported a 630 million franc profit for 1995.
